p: In December 2019, a novel coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak emerged in the city of Wuhan, China. By the beginning of February 2020, The World Health Organization (WHO) formally named the disease triggered by 2019-nCoV as coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The Internal Committee of Taxonomy of Viruses then named the disease severe respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), another Î²-coronavirus cluster related to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) of 2003 and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) of 2012 [1], [2]. As of April 7, 2020, the global pandemic had caused over 1.2 million cases and 72 000 deaths, with numbers rising each day [3].
